title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #534: Maximum GCD-Intersecting Sets**

What is the largest subset A ⊆ {1,...,N} containing N such that gcd(a,b) > 1 for all distinct a,b ∈ A?

**Status:** SOLVED (Ahlswede-Khachatrian 1996)

**Key Result:** The original Erdős-Graham conjecture was WRONG. The correct answer uses multiples of {2q₁,...,2qⱼ, q₁⋯qⱼ}.
mathContext: This is an arithmetic version of intersecting families, where gcd > 1 plays the role of 'shares an element'.

title: Basic Definitions
content:
**interval N:** The set {1, ..., N}.

**IsGCDIntersecting A:** For all distinct a,b ∈ A, gcd(a,b) > 1.

**ContainsN A N:** N ∈ A.

**maxGCDIntersecting N:** The supremum of sizes of valid sets.
mathContext: These definitions set up the optimization problem: maximize |A| subject to A ⊆ {1,...,N}, N ∈ A, and pairwise gcd > 1.

title: Multiples of Smallest Prime
content:
**multiplesOfSmallestPrime N:**

All multiples of p = minFac(N) in {1,...,N}.

This gives a GCD-intersecting set of size N/p.

**Example:** For N = 12, p = 2, giving {2,4,6,8,10,12} with 6 elements.
mathContext: All elements share the factor p, so any pair has gcd ≥ p > 1.

title: Even Multiples Sharing Factor
content:
**evenMultiplesSharing N:**

Even numbers in {1,...,N} that share a factor with N.

All elements are even (gcd ≥ 2) and share factor with N.

This was part of the original (incorrect) conjecture.
mathContext: This construction ensures pairwise gcd > 1 via the factor 2.

title: Original Conjecture (WRONG)
content:
**OriginalConjecture:**

Erdős-Graham conjectured max = max(N/p, |evenMultiplesSharing(N)|).

**original_conjecture_false:** This is FALSE!

**counterexample_exists:** Ahlswede-Khachatrian (1992) found counterexamples.

The maximum can exceed both N/p and the even multiples count.
mathContext: Finding the counterexample required careful analysis of specific N values.

title: Optimal Family Construction
content:
**optimalFamily N j primes:**

Integers in {1,...,N} that are multiples of at least one of:
- 2q₁, 2q₂, ..., 2qⱼ (two times the first j primes of N)
- q₁·q₂·...·qⱼ (product of first j primes)

**ahlswede_khachatrian_theorem:**
For some optimal j, this family achieves the maximum.
mathContext: The key insight is balancing between 2qᵢ terms (many divisors) and the product term (fewer but larger divisors).

title: Special Cases
content:
**prime_power_case:** For N = p^k, max = p^(k-1).

**two_times_prime_case:** For N = 2p (odd prime p), max = 2.

**squarefree_case:** Simplified structure when N is squarefree.
mathContext: Special cases provide insight and are easier to compute.

title: Summary
content:
**erdos_534_characterization:**

1. Original conjecture is FALSE
2. Correct answer uses optimal j from {1,...,ω(N)}
3. Proven by Ahlswede-Khachatrian (1996)

**erdos_534_solved:** Problem is SOLVED.

**erdos_534_status:** "SOLVED - original conjecture was wrong"
mathContext: This was a case where the intuitive conjecture failed and a more sophisticated construction was needed.
